items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: High river levels today, 14 January 2026, may lead to flooding. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Church Laneham to Rampton Road. There is the potential for moderate rainfall Thursday afternoon/evening but low confidence in the forecast. River levels at Torksey Gauge will remain high until the 15/01/2026. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10:00am on 15/01/26 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent rainfall and snow melt. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.

River levels at Pillings Lock Gauge will remain high over the next few days. There is minimal further rainfall forecast today, 14/01/2026. We are closely monitoring the situation & checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 17:00PM on 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Flooding is expected.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected from the River Cherwell especially near Enslow, Thrupp and Kidlington. These high river levels are due to the heavy rainfall we saw last Thursday. The water has now made its way down the river. The weather forecast today (Wednesday 14 January) is mostly dry with a few showers in places. Thursday is expected to be wet, with persistent rain which will be heavy in places. We expect river levels to drop today and tomorrow, and then slightly re-rise on Friday and Saturday in response to tomorrow's rain.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 12:00 pm, midday, on the 15 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
River levels are high on parts of the River Windrush. Therefore flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible today, near Newbridge. The weather forecast today (Wednesday 14 January) is mostly dry with a few showers in places. Thursday is expected to be wet, with persistent rain which will be heavy in places. We expect river levels to rise in response and to remain high over the weekend.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 12:00 pm, midday, on the 15 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
If you have been evacuated only return to your property once the emergency services have advised that it is safe to do so. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.message:
This flood alert remains in place due to the significant rainfall forecast for tomorrow, Thursday 15th January 2026.

Flooding remains possible for low lying land, roads and footpaths close to the river in the Horley area.

We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further messages where necessary. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 08:00 tomorrow morning, 15th January 2026, or as the situation changes.

We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 14 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Rising river levels today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 14 January 2026 from approximately 1800 hours. 
River levels on the River Mole near Cobham continue to rise. Flooding is likely on low lying land, roads and footpaths close to the river in this area. The levels in the river at Sidlow, Brockham, Leatherhead and Dorking are falling, however further rainfall is likely to cause the river to rise again and flooding in these areas may occur tomorrow, 15th January 2026. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further messages as required. 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 8:00AM on 15 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are starting to fall following rain on Tuesday 13 January.  With further heavy rain expected throughout the day on Thursday 15 January, river levels are expected to rise once again leading to increased flooding of low lying land and roads around Balls Green, Ashurst and Penshurst.
We continue to monitor rainfall and river levels.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00am on 15 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels on the mid Bristol Avon and Semington Brook have now peaked and are beginning to fall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Semington Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.

Further rain is forecast during Thursday and river levels are likely to rise again in response to this rain.  We are closely monitoring the situation and clearing debris from weed screens. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated on Thursday morning, or sooner if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels remain high but are starting to fall following rain on Tuesday 13 January.  With further heavy rain expected throughout the day on Thursday 15 January, river levels are expected to rise once again leading to increased flooding of low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Water Lane and Lingfield.
We continue to monitor rainfall and river levels.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00am on 15 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River remains high, but is now slowly falling, following Tuesday's rain. Only isolated showers are forecast Wednesday night. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields near North Street, River Lane, and The Old Clergy House, Alfriston. In Hellingly, minor flood impacts affecting fields and gardens will ease Wednesday evening. Widespread 20-40mm rain is forecast Thursday and river levels are expected to rise again. Property flooding could be possible Thursday evening. We are closely monitoring the situation. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Avoid roads that flood (Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly, North Street, Alfriston). This message will be updated by 15:00 15/01/2026.

The Western Rother remains high and slowly rising in Fittleworth, following Tuesday's rain. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields and gardens at Lodsbridge, near Selham, and near Fittleworth Mill. In Liss, river levels have already returned near to normal. Between Iping and Selham river levels are falling. Only isolated showers are forecast on Wednesday evening. River levels at Fittleworth are not expected to rise significantly higher, and should begin to fall by 15:00 14/01/2026 near Selham, and 23:00 14/01/2026 near Fittleworth. Widespread 20-40mm rain is forecast Thursday and river levels are expected to rise again. Property flooding could be possible Thursday evening. We are closely monitoring the situation. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have. Including in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. Avoid roads that flood (Iping). This message will be updated by 15:00 15/01/2026.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester
items.message:
River levels are falling and will continue to fall over the coming days. Access should now be available via Townfield Lane.
Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington.
We are continuing to monitor the situation and will provide further updates as the situation changes.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 15 January 2026.

A flood alert has been updated by the Environment Agency. 
Flood alert in force: Bourne Brook (Tamworth) 
Flooding is possible for: Low-lying land and roads between Shenstone and Fazeley 
High river levels today may lead to flooding.  
Flooding is possible today, 14 January 2026 .  
Flooding may affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the Bourne Brook.  
We are closely monitoring the situation Further scattered showers are possible throughout today.  
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses..  
 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 15 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high today. Flooding may continue on 14 January 2026. Flooding may affect low lying land & roads adjacent to the river from Highley to Tewkesbury; including Dog Lane Bewdley, Stourport, Diglis & Hylton Road towpath. Flooded drains affect the racecourse & Worcester CCG. PLP should be installed. New St Gate closed at Upton upon Severn. Predicted peaks:- Worcester 4.1m to 4.3m on 14/01 AM, Diglis 3.9m to 4.0m on 14/01 AM, Kempsey Yacht Club 5.9m to 6.1m on 14/01 AM, Saxons Lode 4.5m to 4.6m on 14/01 AM. Other gauge locations are not forecast to exceed Flood Alert thresholds. Further rainfall is forecast on Thursday 15/01. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 15 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high today. Flooding may continue on 14 January 2026. Flooding may affect low lying land and Squires Walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Kempsey Flood Alleviation Scheme is currently operational. Predicted peak:- Kempsey Yacht Club 5.9m to 6.1m 14/01 AM. We are closely monitoring the situation. Further rainfall is forecast on Thursday 15/01. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses . This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 15 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. There is the potential for moderate rainfall Thursday afternoon/evening but low confidence in the forecast. River levels at Willington and Shardlow Gauge are likely to remain high until 19/01/26. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10:00am on 15/01/26 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible in the West Dorset area. Groundwater levels are high in response to heavy rainfall earlier in December. Levels are slowly falling but remain high, and flooding of fields and roads is still possible. Groundwater levels are falling but further rainfall in the coming days may lead to levels rising once more. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 20th January 2026 or as the situation changes.

This message will be updated by 10:00am on 15 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

High river levels today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 14 January 2026 . 
Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking rainfall and river levels. 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water Avoid low lying roads near river which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 15 January 2026 or as the situation changes.
